funFacts: Chinese has over 50,000 characters, but everyday literacy needs about 3,500; most MT engines map ~100,000 English lemmas to these 3,500 core characters.
Until 2015 Google Translate often output ‘I am gay’ for ‘我很快乐’ because ‘快乐’ (happy) was aligned with ‘gay’ in older bilingual corpora.
The greeting ‘吃了吗?’ literally means ‘Have you eaten?’; naïve translators render it word-for-word, missing its function as ‘How are you?’.
Tone in Mandarin (four main tones) is ignored in text-only machine translation, which is why Pinyin without tone marks can create ambiguity for learners.

Simplified Chinese was introduced in the 1950s to boost literacy; Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and many overseas communities still use Traditional characters, so one English sentence can yield at least two written Chinese versions.
